data:
Introducing NetAIGym (Network AI Gym), an open Simulation-as-a-Service framework to revolutionize Network AI Research and Development. NetAIGym comprises three key components, each playing a vital role in the framework:


NetAIClient: This Python-based interface that offers researchers and developers a comprehensive development environment following the Open AI Gym/Gymnasium standards.
It caters to the development of both AI and non-AI algorithms, empowering users with a versatile toolkit such as Stable-Baselines3 and WanDB.
NetAIGym API: Open API for collecting data and interacting with the simulated network environment.
NetAIServer & NetAISim: Leverage open-source network simulation tools, e.g., ns-3; Enhance it with customized capabilities & use-cases, e.g. Traffic Steering, Network Slicing, Distributed Compute, Dynamic QoS, Energy Saving, etc.
data.-out-of-scope#âŒ Out-of-Scope:
Develop proprietary AI algorithms or models
Develop AI application or software, e.g. xApp/rApp, etc., based on controller architecture, e.g. O-RAN RIC, etc.
Develop â€œDigital Twinâ€ to simulate the physical world with high fidelity
data.ï¸-in-scope#âœ”ï¸ In-Scope:
Develop open & reference AI models/algos for networking research (Layer 2 & above)
Develop abstract models, e.g. channel, compute, power, etc. for the physical world & system
Develop full-stack models to simulate E2E (Access/Edge/Cloud) network operation with high fidelity





Get started â†’

data:
We have hosted NetAIServer and NetAISim on vLab machines to collaborate with MLWiNS/RINGs universities.
Using the provided NetAIGym Open API, a NetAIClient can establish a connection with the NetAIServer via the public internet or Intel's internal network.
Contact us to get the early access to NetAIGym.Next, we plan to launch NetAIGym Sim-aaS via Intel DevCloud and make it available for all Intel developers.
In the meantime, we are collaborating with the research community to enhance NetAISim with new use-cases & capabilities, e.g., 5G/O-RAN, distributed computing, RAN energy saving, predictive QoS, etc.
data.launch-your-first-network-ai-simulation#: With the early access to NetAIGym, download the client software NetAIClient to launch your first simulation. See the NetAIClient Github Repository for more details about the client software.
data.when-the-netaiclient-starts#When the Net: NetAIClient sends a JSON configure file to NetAIServer to launch a ns-3 simulation.
data.when-the-simulation-is-running-the-follo:
NetAISim collects and sends measurement metrics to NetAIServer, which forwards measurements to the NetAIClient via the NetAIGym Open API.
(AI or non-AI) Algorithm Agent computes an action based on the measurements, and stores data in WandB.
NetAIClient transmits the action to the NetAISim via the NetAIGym Open API. NetAISim will take the new action and continue the simulation.
data.when-the-netaiclientsimulation-ends#When: The data stored in Wandb can be conveniently visualized on the Wandb website.

data:
Showcase

Open source projects powered by NetAIGym

Introducing NetAIGym (Network AI Gym), an open Simulation-as-a-Service framework to revolutionize Network AI Research and Development. NetAIGym comprises three key components, each playing a vital role in the framework:


NetAIClient: This Python-based interface that offers researchers and developers a comprehensive development environment following the Open AI Gym/Gymnasium standards.
It caters to the development of both AI and non-AI algorithms, empowering users with a versatile toolkit such as Stable-Baselines3 and WanDB.
NetAIGym API: Open API for collecting data and interacting with the simulated network environment.
NetAIServer & NetAISim: Leverage open-source network simulation tools, e.g., ns-3; Enhance it with customized capabilities & use-cases, e.g. Traffic Steering, Network Slicing, Distributed Compute, Dynamic QoS, Energy Saving, etc.
data.-out-of-scope#âŒ Out-of-Scope:
Develop proprietary AI algorithms or models
Develop AI application or software, e.g. xApp/rApp, etc., based on controller architecture, e.g. O-RAN RIC, etc.
Develop â€œDigital Twinâ€ to simulate the physical world with high fidelity
data.ï¸-in-scope#âœ”ï¸ In-Scope:
Develop open & reference AI models/algos for networking research (Layer 2 & above)
Develop abstract models, e.g. channel, compute, power, etc. for the physical world & system
Develop full-stack models to simulate E2E (Access/Edge/Cloud) network operation with high fidelity

data.openai-gymgymnasium#OpenAI Gym/Gymnasium: Gymnasium is a standard API for reinforcement learning, and a diverse collection of reference environments.
data.ns-3#ns-3: ns-3 is a discrete-event network simulator for Internet systems, targeted primarily for research and educational use. ns-3 is free, open-source software, licensed under the GNU GPLv2 license, and maintained by a worldwide community.
data.ns-3-community#ns-3 community:
Number of publications involving ns-3: A search of the â€˜ns-3 simulatorâ€™ results on https://scholar.google.com
since 2017 (excluding patents and citations) yieldsÂ over 17,300 linksÂ (with some false positives).
The ACM digital library lists 11,830 publications matching the search term â€˜ns-3â€™ (in abstract) since 2017(searched 6/15/23).
ns-3-users group: As of January 2018, there wereÂ 8183 membersÂ of theÂ ns-3-users group. The number of posts to the ns-3-users group can be viewedÂ at this web page. In 2017, there were approximatelyÂ 700 posts/month.
ns-developers mailing list: TheÂ ns-developers mailing listÂ is where software development discussions take place. As of January 2018, there wereÂ 1560 subscribersÂ to this list.
Number of authors: As of ns-3.27 release,Â 220 peopleÂ are listed as authors in theÂ AUTHORS file.
Number of maintainers: ns-3 maintainers have responsibility and authority to oversee and maintain different portions of the codebase. As of ns-3.27 release,Â 23 peopleÂ areÂ listed as ns-3 maintainers.
Number of downloads: The project has not been maintaining counts of downloads for the past few years. In 2016 (the last year counted), ns-3 releases were downloaded approximatelyÂ 72,000 timesÂ from the main web server.

data:
The source files for the GMA module are located at contrib/gma/ folder.
The source files for the RMCAT (NADA) module are located at contrib/ns3-rmcat/ folder.
The example scripts are located at scratch/ folder.
data.pre-requisite#Pre-requisite:
Clone this repo.
Install ZeroMQ library. We only need the C library. Not the C++ one. For Linux:


apt-get install libczmq-dev
or
apt-get install libzmq5 libzmq3-dev
data.option-1-launch-a-ns-3-example-script#Op:
Build ns-3. Please refer the official ns-3 documentation (attached in the end) for more details.
Run the following scrip to start a NS3 simulation:


mkdir output;
./ns3 run scratch/scratch-simulator.cc --cwd=output
data.option-2-launch-ns-3-as-netaisim-workers:
Setup GMA Database Server, GMA Algorithm Client and InfluxDB as described in the gma-db-server Repo. (This step is required if you want to launch the ns3 as the NetAISim worker for the GMA Database Server.)
Run the following scrip to start multiple NetAISim Workers for the GMA database server.
You will be asked to input the number of workers. 5 workers will be created if no input is detected.




Python3 start start-gmasim-workers.py

data.how-to-use-3rd-party-library-in-ns3-eg-p:
In summery, after installing the 3rd party package, modify the CMakeList.txt file located in the scratch folder to include the package, assuming the examples are also inside the scratch folders. The detailed steps are as follows:
Install Prometheus.
Clone and build prometheus-cpp server/client that write/read to/from Prometheus database.
Change the IP and Port # for the server_sample, e.g., Exposer exposer{"10.23.36.169:9090"};
The executables are located at ./_build/bin/ folder.
Follow the Packaging section to create a .deb file and install it.
Check if the packet is installed by apt list --installed | grep prometheus-cpp


Modify the ns-3's CMakeLists.txt located in the scratch folder (assume the example scripts are inside the scratch folder):
add find_package(prometheus-cpp CONFIG REQUIRED)
add prometheus-cpp::pull to the target_link_libraries


Enjoy !!!

data: Let me try somethinf.

We have hosted NetAIServer and NetAISim on vLab machines to collaborate with MLWiNS/RINGs universities. Using the provided NetAIGym Open API, a NetAIClient can establish a connection with the NetAIServer via the public internet or Intel's internal network.  Next, we plan to launch NetAIGym Sim-aaS via Intel DevCloud and make it available for all Intel developers. In the meantime, we are collaborating with the research community to enhance NetAISim with new use-cases & capabilities, e.g., 5G/O-RAN, distributed computing, RAN energy saving, predictive QoS, etc.
Let me try somethinf.

data.netaigym-early-access--alpha-testing#Net:
We have hosted NetAIServer and NetAISim on vLab machines to collaborate with MLWiNS/RINGs universities.
Using the provided NetAIGym Open API, a NetAIClient can establish a connection with the NetAIServer via the public internet or Intel's internal network.
Contact us to get the early access to NetAIGym.Next, we plan to launch NetAIGym Sim-aaS via Intel DevCloud and make it available for all Intel developers.
In the meantime, we are collaborating with the research community to enhance NetAISim with new use-cases & capabilities, e.g., 5G/O-RAN, distributed computing, RAN energy saving, predictive QoS, etc.
data.start-your-first-network-ai-simulation#S:
After the early access to NetAIGym is granted. You can download the NetAIClient to launch your first simulation. See the NetAIClient Github Repository for more information about configuring the client software.
A simulation run can be described by the following Five steps.
data.when-the-netaiclient-starts#When the Net: NetAIClient sends a JSON configure file to NetAIServer to launch a ns-3 simulation.
data.when-the-simulation-is-running-the-follo:
NetAISim collects and sends measurement metrics to NetAIServer, which forwards measurements to the NetAIClient via the NetAIGym Open API.
(AI or non-AI) Algorithm Agent computes an action based on the measurements, and stores data in WandB.
NetAIClient transmits the action to the NetAISim via the NetAIGym Open API. NetAISim will continue the simulation with the new action.
data.when-the-simulation-stops#When the simul: The measurement history can be visualized via the WanDB website.

data: Let me try somethinf.
The NetAIGym Open API now support Ten measurement metrics and Three use cases.
data.a-list-of-supported-measurement-metrics#: Measurement	Unit	Description	max_rate	mbps	LTE/Wi-Fi link capacity measured by each user	load	mbps	Input traffic throughput measured by each user	rate	mbps	Output traffic throughput measured by each user, including LTE, Wi-Fi, and ALL	qos_rate	mbps	Output traffic throughput that meet the QoS requirement measured by each user, including LTE, Wi-Fi, and ALL	owd	ms	One-way delay measured by each user, including LTE, Wi-Fi, and ALL	tsu		The traffic split ratio measured by each user, including LTE, Wi-Fi	ap_id		The access-point/cell ID measured by each user, including LTE and Wi-Fi	slice_id		LTE slice ID measured by each user	rb_usage	%	LTE resource block usage percentage (%) measured by each user	delay_violation	%	Packet One-way delay violation percentage (%) measured by each user
data.a-list-of-supported-use-cases-and-action: Use-Case	Action	Description	Multi-Access (MX) Traffic Splitting	Traffic Splitting	update traffic split ratio of a flow over Wi-Fi and LTE	QoS-aware MX Traffic Steering	Traffic Steering	steer traffic over Wi-Fi or LTE for a flow	Cellular RAN Slicing	Resource Allocation	update LTE resource block allocation ratio for a slice

data.ns-3#ns-3: ns-3 is a discrete-event network simulator for Internet systems, targeted primarily for research and educational use. ns-3 is free, open-source software, licensed under the GNU GPLv2 license, and maintained by a worldwide community.
data.ns-3-community#ns-3 community:
Number of publications involving ns-3: A search of the â€˜ns-3 simulatorâ€™ results on https://scholar.google.com
since 2017 (excluding patents and citations) yieldsÂ over 17,300 linksÂ (with some false positives).
The ACM digital library lists 11,830 publications matching the search term â€˜ns-3â€™ (in abstract) since 2017(searched 6/15/23).
ns-3-users group: As of January 2018, there wereÂ 8183 membersÂ of theÂ ns-3-users group. The number of posts to the ns-3-users group can be viewedÂ at this web page. In 2017, there were approximatelyÂ 700 posts/month.
ns-developers mailing list: TheÂ ns-developers mailing listÂ is where software development discussions take place. As of January 2018, there wereÂ 1560 subscribersÂ to this list.
Number of authors: As of ns-3.27 release,Â 220 peopleÂ are listed as authors in theÂ AUTHORS file.
Number of maintainers: ns-3 maintainers have responsibility and authority to oversee and maintain different portions of the codebase. As of ns-3.27 release,Â 23 peopleÂ areÂ listed as ns-3 maintainers.
Number of downloads: The project has not been maintaining counts of downloads for the past few years. In 2016 (the last year counted), ns-3 releases were downloaded approximatelyÂ 72,000 timesÂ from the main web server.

data: Stable Baselines3 (SB3) is a set of reliable implementations of reinforcement learning algorithms in PyTorch. It is the next major version of Stable Baselines.Github repository: https://github.com/DLR-RM/stable-baselines3Paper: https://jmlr.org/papers/volume22/20-1364/20-1364.pdfRL Baselines3 Zoo (training framework for SB3): https://github.com/DLR-RM/rl-baselines3-zooRL Baselines3 Zoo provides a collection of pre-trained agents, scripts for training, evaluating agents, tuning hyperparameters, plotting results and recording videos.SB3 Contrib (experimental RL code, latest algorithms): https://github.com/Stable-Baselines-Team/stable-baselines3-contrib

ZeroMQ (also spelled Ã˜MQ, 0MQ or ZMQ) is a high-performance asynchronous messaging library, aimed at use in distributed or concurrent applications. It provides a message queue, but unlike message-oriented middleware, a ZeroMQ system can run without a dedicated message broker.ZeroMQ supports common messaging patterns (pub/sub, request/reply, client/server and others) over a variety of transports (TCP, in-process, inter-process, multicast, WebSocket and more), making inter-process messaging as simple as inter-thread messaging. This keeps your code clear, modular and extremely easy to scale.ZeroMQ is developed by a large community of contributors. There are third-party bindings for many popular programming languages and native ports for C# and Java.

News

Stay tuned for NetAIGym's news update.

data.network-ai-developer-challenges-why-neta:
real-world dataset controlled by network operator, difficult to acquire, not aligned with specific usage or requirement.
dataset by itself not enough, also need environment to train/test AI models, e.g. Reinforcement Learning, etc.
network simulation tools (e.g., ns3, etc.) often very complex and difficult to use, especially for Network AI researcher & developer.

âš ï¸Gap: lack of common simulation environment with simple APIs to develop, evaluate, and benchmark Network AI models & algorithms.
